editorialDecl.p: Encoding of this text has followed the recommendations of the LombardPress 1.0.0 guidelines for a critical edition.

change.p: Created file for the first time.

div.head: Question 23
Whether quality admits of a greater or lesser degree
div.p: Whether quality admits of a greater or lesser degree.

I respond that this proposition should be distinguished according to the composed and divided sense. The composite sense is impossible because no quality takes a greater and lesser at the same time. The divided sense is true and this is with respect to the logic of the question. With respect the matter he puts that color has some latitude Nevertheless, that color has latitude is able to be understood in two ways.

In one mode thus that it does not really have distinct intermediates, just as is true about time and motion because an hour and a year are not really distinguished just as Socrates in the forum and Socrates in the theater are not really distinguished. But when it is said that time has parts, one of which is day and another is year or hour, these propositions ought to be understood thus, hour is part of day and this thing, as it is an hour, lasts less than an a day or a year. Or it is able to be explained thus, the following proposition is true longer in this region the heavens are day than this proposition in the same region the heavens are now in the ninth hour. And in this way it should be conceded that time has intermediaries. And then not in another sense unless this: the heavens, as it is hour, does not thus last longer, just as the heavens, as it is a year or double time to a year or an hour. And it is in the same way concerning the latitude of heat, for the same thing is the latitude of heat and heat. And the latitude of heat has parts, just as time because the same heat, as it is in the process of changing is called 'latitude', and when it is changed is called heat and not latitude.
In another mode, having really distinct intermediaries could be to be conceded or be understood intensively, and this sense beckons and denies.

In a third mode, it is possible for having distinct intermediaries to be understood extensively according to the intermediaries of the subject, and thus he concedes that both time and motion have really distinct intermediaries, just the heavens themselves have because there is not a latitude except the heat itself.

I respond to the first argument that, if fire in the highest degree ought to generate from water fire in the highest degree, it should not be imagined that continuously in the beginning of the action of fire the latitude of heat is led into water. Rather there is a successive corruption of the water. and it does not lead some heat of fire nor the form of fire before an ultimate instant of corruption of water, and then immediately will lead to the highest fire and highest color.

Again, in solving the second principale argument, where he inquires, whether contraries at the same time are coextended in the same subject, he holds that this is not so on account of many arguments,
Item in solvendo 2m principale ubi inquirit
utrum contraria simul coextendantur in eodem
subiecto tenet quod non propter multas rationes dicens
quod quando ex aliqua generatur ignis non est ymaginandum
quod subito corumpatur et deinde generetur ignis
et intendatur successive nec quod per medem
tempus in quo transmutabitur n?ra aliquae corrum
patur tota aliqua successive et in alia mediate inten
datur forma ignis successive set successive
corrumpetur aqua et subito generabitur forma
ignis et eius caliditas ita quod non generatur
caliditas antequam tota frigiditas corrumpatur
illa tamen caliditas per quam aqua dicitur calida est
eadem res cum frigiditate aquae et frigiditas
remissa aquae est caliditas accidentalis unde non
sunt calores eiusdem speciei quia caliditas
accidentalis aquae est alterius speciei quam calor
ignis et eiusdem cum frigide aquae et ideo
aqua calefacta redit ad frigiditatem sine agen
te extrinseco unde proprie non alterat se quia
alteratio est proprie remissio formae contrariae
formae agentis unde illa qualitas quando fit
debelior causalitas nonremittitur set neccesse
dicitur et causa est quia illa caliditas est essentialiter fri
giditas et accidentaliter calor

Item secundum
eundem corruptio rei naturales non est contraria ge
nerationi suae per eosdem gradus set ge
neratio ignis ex aqua erit ex contraria
corruptione formae aquae et suae frigiditate
et generatio aquae ex illa erit ex successiva
corruptione in latitudine ignis et suae caliditas
et subito generabitur aqua et sua frigiditatis
et sic salvat quod est accipere primum instans rei per
maneret in esse et ita ultimum et qualitas mo
tus denotatur a posteriori passione secundum
ymaginationem conceditur 8 physicorum commento 69
quod caliditas in aqua sit essentialiter frigiditas
probat sic per signum quia caliditas in aqua remit
tat
caliditatem aeque calido cum aqua set consequentia
non est quod alia caliditas remittit caliditatem
eiusdem speciei Si autem dicitur quod si caliditas
in aqua est essentialiter frigiditas quare
non repraesentat sensum frigiditatem set ca
liditatem respondet quod sicut album positum a remotis
per intensionem remissam repraesentat vi
sui nigredinem vel co?ie medium ita fri
giditas aquae multum remissa repraesentat
caliditatem

Nota quod idem calor potest esse in
tentior quam iam est sine additione alicuius
quia faciat deus duas medietates calorum
simul coextendi in eodem situ igitur est duplo
intentior quam prius Set contra hoc non arguit
quia sic calor christi foret intentior quam
calor alicuius alterius quia eius medietas est
in eodem situ et medietas illarum et sic in
infinitum dicitur quod non est ad propositum quia calor
christi in sacramento non est ibi localiter nec
situaliter ideo etc
